title: Rule of 7s for Lyme Meningitis
description: Distinguishes Lyme meningitis from aseptic meningitis in pediatric patients (ages 2-18) in Lyme endemic areas. This validated clinical prediction rule identifies children at low risk for Lyme meningitis who can be managed as outpatients while awaiting Lyme serology results, potentially avoiding unnecessary hospitalizations and parenteral antibiotics.

parameters.name: headache_days
parameters.description: Number of days of headache symptoms prior to presentation

parameters.name: csf_mononuclear_percentage
parameters.description: Percentage of mononuclear cells in cerebrospinal fluid analysis

parameters.name: cranial_nerve_palsy
parameters.description: Presence of seventh (facial) or other cranial nerve palsy on clinical examination

result.name: rule_of_7s_score
result.description: Rule of 7s score ranging from 0-3 points based on clinical criteria

ranges.interpretation: Low risk for Lyme meningitis (<10% probability). Patient meets all three 'Rule of 7s' criteria for low risk: <7 days of headache, <70% CSF mononuclear cells, and no cranial nerve palsy. These children can be safely managed as outpatients while awaiting Lyme serology results. Consider discharge home with close outpatient follow-up, symptomatic treatment, and clear return precautions. Avoid unnecessary hospitalization and empirical parenteral antibiotics. Ensure proper follow-up within 24-48 hours and clear instructions for return if symptoms worsen.

ranges.stage: Not Low Risk for Lyme Meningitis
ranges.description: Consider inpatient management and empirical treatment
ranges.interpretation: Not low risk for Lyme meningitis - higher probability of Lyme meningitis cannot be excluded. Patient does not meet all criteria for low risk classification by the Rule of 7s. Consider inpatient management with empirical antibiotic treatment for Lyme meningitis while awaiting confirmatory serology results. Initiate appropriate antibiotics (ceftriaxone) if clinical suspicion is high. Monitor closely for neurologic complications and clinical deterioration. Obtain comprehensive Lyme serology testing and consider additional diagnostic evaluation as clinically indicated.

formula: Rule of 7s Score = sum of points for: (1) ≥7 days of headache (1 point), (2) ≥70% CSF mononuclear cells (1 point), (3) Presence of cranial nerve palsy (1 point). Score of 0 = Low risk (<10% probability of Lyme meningitis), Score 1-3 = Not low risk
notes: Rule of 7s distinguishes Lyme meningitis from aseptic meningitis in children ages 2-18
Only applicable in Lyme disease-endemic areas with CSF pleocytosis (≥10 WBC/mm³)
Score of 0 points indicates low risk for Lyme meningitis (<10% probability)
Score of 1-3 points indicates not low risk for Lyme meningitis
Low risk patients can be managed as outpatients while awaiting serology
Validated with 96% sensitivity and 41% specificity for low risk identification
Requires correction of CSF cell count if RBC >500 cells/mm³
Not a definitive diagnostic test - clinical decision aid only
Requires close outpatient follow-up for low risk patients
Consider empirical antibiotic treatment for non-low risk patients
Performance validated in multiple pediatric cohort studies
More practical than complex mathematical prediction models
Helps avoid unnecessary hospitalizations in low risk patients
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment
Limited to pediatric population - not validated in adults
Requires presence of CSF pleocytosis for application
Cranial nerve palsy most commonly involves facial nerve (CN VII)
Rule applies only to children with suspected CNS infection
Geographic limitation to Lyme-endemic regions
May need seasonal consideration in endemic areas
